ratings.question_text: Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: Began as two days a week of virtual synchronous seminar and two days a week of asynchronous videos on youtube. Mid-way through the semester it transitioned to two days a week of synchronous lectures with one day a week of small group work and two days a week of asynchronous videos.
Live virtual lecture and virtual discussion format
only live lectures
There were synchronous and asynchronous components for this course.
We met synchronously in a virtual seminar three times a week and asynchronously  two times a week, in which we watched online videos.
We also had a weekly discussion section with the TA
Had some office hour sessions.

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Arabic 110 with Professor Elbousty was nothing short of amazing. He is a caring and compassionate professor who is dedicated to ensuring that each student in his class learn and understand the material. While taking this course during my first semester at Yale, I learned about the Islamic culture, the Arabic alphabet, a ton of useful vocabulary that I continue to use in my everyday life.
I learned about the basics of the Arabic Language. I learned most about the alphabet and how to read the Arabic script.
Introductory reading, writing, listening, and speaking skills in Arabic as well as knowledge of the Arabic alphabet and basic grammar patterns,
We learned how to read and write basic arabic, starting with understanding the alphabet.
Learned basic Arabic including the alphabet and some grammar patterns.
A basic knowledge of the Arabic alphabet as well as introduction to basic sentence structure and verb conjugation.

I learnt how to read and write in Arabic, and I learnt basic Arabic grammar and vocabulary to have conversations about myself and to ask about the other persons family, favorite food etc. I also learnt about the other dialects in Arabic and about the Arabic culture by listening to popular Arabic music and making a final project with my group members on a Arab country.

I not only learned part of a new language, but beneficial ways of studying something completely foreign. The course taught me how to deal with a complex subject matter over a relatively short period of time---breaking down the alphabet, pronunciation etc.
I learned SO much in this class. I learned conversational Arabic, the alphabet and numbering system, greetings and grammar, and the cultural world of Arabic!

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: A major strength of this course is that Professor Elbousty has patience when interacting with his students. He understands that the Arabic language is diffcult to learn and takes his time when reviewing new information. This course moves at a decent pace to where I managed to keep up with the workload each week.  Additionally, I found the discussion section with the T.A to be extremely helpful. The only weakness of this course is that it was taught remotely, which prevents students from receiving the full experience of interacting and engaing with a new foreign language.

Strengths: It was very engaging in the first half of the semester when we had practices in talking in the language. 
Places to improve: Halfway through the semester, when the classes just became lectures, I felt less engaged with the class. I feel like the lectures could have been posted ahead of time and in class, we actually did engaging activities.

The course did a great job introducing us to the language and exposing us to culture. I felt like the different sorts of activities certainly helped gain different language skills, but having more time to practice speaking with other students would be very helpful.

The class is very interactive and Professor Elbousty is very passionate about teaching. At times, however, the course moves too fast so I needed to spend a significant amount of time outside class to catch up.

Strengths: amazing T.A. 
Weaknesses: the professor

Given that this course is an intro language, I feel that instruction as frequent as possible is best for improvement and confidence in learning the new language. While I know the department decided it was best to lecture 2-3 times a week, I believe that at least 4 times a week with live instruction from the professor would result in the most growth and confidence from the students.

This course had many strengths including the copious amounts of support offered to us when we were struggling with new concepts. This is very important for learning a new language such as Arabic, since it is important to ensure that we understand the basic concepts of grammar in Arabic. The TF for the class, Bayan, helped us a lot in our weekly sections in which she went over difficult topics for that week for example forming plurals in Arabic. Additionally, the instructor Professor Elbousty and Bayan were very supportive and passionate teachers. They were very patient and always took their time to explain something that was difficult when we had questions. The class was also paced very well for learning Arabic, in order to give us enough time to understand concepts but also to keep our level of engagement high. The online videos were also very helpful, and helped to supplement our learning of concepts in class. One weakness of the course was that sometimes it was confusing which website we submit our homework to, but this was more of a technical issue.

The highlight of this course was Professor Elbousty. His dedication and flexibility proved invaluable. It was clear that he wanted us to not just learn Arabic, but be surrounded by it with songs, shows, group projects, etc. The only issue I had was through submission dates/places, but that may be a canvas issue rather than something with the course.

Strengths: Professor Elboustys love for Arabic showed through every minute of this class. I appreciated how the material was given at a pace that took into account everyones situations and personal questions. 

Weaknesses: Very few! I wish we did speaking more towards the end of the year and received practice that was similar to the test!

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Overall, the virtual format was utilized as well as it could be. Grammar presentations were very helpful, as well as discussion section and activities from the textbook.
The professor needs to be more involved in teaching as it was clear the course was the least of his concerns.

I thought that learning through zoom was fine; I feel I could have benefited from more frequent lessons in Arabic. My professor was a fantastic teacher and I just would like more time with the professor as I progress in Arabic, considering that under normal circumstances the course meets 5 times a week.

Learning a language over Zoom is extremely difficult but this class managed to make it very engaging and successful. The breakout rooms were really great for practicing conversational skills in Arabic and for meeting other classmates. The virtual seminar format was also very effective especially when Professor Elbousty shared his screen so that we can see his PowerPoint or a video talking about an Arabic grammar rule. The weekly TF sections were also very effective, in which Bayan shared her screen and wrote on her iPad like a whiteboard. This was highly effective in simulating a classroom experience and keeping everyone engaged.

Flexibility was key. Being able to meet with our TA once a week with specific questions, expanded deadlines, group projects within our meeting time and optional Saturday review sessions were all invaluable. Given the circumstances, the course was organized and adapted very well.
I appreciated all the PowerPoints and online discussion sections. Both were very helpful.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I would most definitely recommend this course to another student. The Arabic langauge is a beautiful langauge that everyone should learn if given the opportunity. Before taking this course, I had no prior experience speaking Arabic, but now I can hold small conversations, read and write in MSA. Proferssor Elbousty is a phenomenal professor who will help to build your knowledge and confidence while exploring this amazing language.
Yes. If they are interested in learning Arabic, this was an excellent introduction to the language.
I would definitely recommend this course to someone who is interested in learning Arabic. However, they should be ready for the significant workload outside of class.
No. If you want to take Arabic 110, wait for another professor to teach.
If someone was interested in learning Arabic I would certainly encourage them to take the course at Yale.

I would highly recommend this course to another student that wants to learn Arabic or learn another language that is challenging but very rewarding. Arabic is a beautiful language filled with history and nuances, and this course makes you excited to learn about it because of the highly passionate teachers and course material.

Certainly. It is a heck of a challenge to learn Arabic without any background, but it is a very understanding environment. If one puts in the daily work, they would be surprised with how much they progress.

Dr. Jonas is an incredible teacher. He is pleasant, understanding, and full of knowledge. He truly cares about his students wants them to succeed. I loved his class. Generally, it's a joy to be in class, and it isn't boring at all. He wants you to leave his class better than you came in. He indeed will have you prepared to the next level. I would definitely recommend Dr. Jonas! I've learned a lot, not only basic stuff but also how to think critically and intellectually.
Absolutely. Deciding to take a completely new language is certainly a challenge, yet Prof. Elbousty is here each step of the way to help you through it.
